cards.title: Snappy snaps: underwater shots of eels, sharks and crocs
cards.rawTitle: Snappy snaps: underwater shots of eels, sharks and crocs

item.title: Snappy snaps: underwater shots of eels, sharks and crocs
item.trailText: Photographer Matty Smith ventures beneath the water’s surface to take fascinating – and often risky – images of the creatures that inhabit our oceans
item.standFirst: From the mangroves of Cuba to the inlets of New South Wales, photographer Matty Smith ventures beneath the surface of the water to take fascinating – and often risky – pictures of the creatures that inhabit our oceans. For his show A Parallel Universe, he says, every image was ‘taken in the wild on the animal’s terms and as true as my eye saw it’. Here’s a selection of the best

displayImages.caption:
Smiling Assassin: American saltwater crocodile, Jardines de la Reina, Cuba Smith says: ‘Now my photography has led me into a few interesting situations in the past, but this takes the cake. One of the most exhilarating moments of my life.’


All photographs: Matty Smith
displayImages.altText: Smiling Assassin - American Saltwater Crocodile, Jardines de la Reina, Cuba
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Smiling Assassin: American saltwater crocodile, Jardines de la Reina, Cuba Smith says: ‘Now my photography has led me into a few interesting situations in the past, but this takes the cake. One of the most exhilarating moments of my life.’


All photographs: Matty Smith

displayImages.caption: Crimson Tide: waratah anemones, Port Kembla, Australia ‘During my lunchbreak walk, I found this tiny rockpool containing these wonderful bright-red waratah anemones. I just had to make a picture of them. I knew I could only shoot at the lowest of tides and I wanted it to coincide with a nice sunrise. It was to be a long waiting game.’
displayImages.altText: Crimson Tide - Waratah Anemones, Port Kembla, NSW Australia
displayImages.cleanCaption: Crimson Tide: waratah anemones, Port Kembla, Australia ‘During my lunchbreak walk, I found this tiny rockpool containing these wonderful bright-red waratah anemones. I just had to make a picture of them. I knew I could only shoot at the lowest of tides and I wanted it to coincide with a nice sunrise. It was to be a long waiting game.’

displayImages.caption: Bluebottle Army: a Portuguese man o’ war (AKA bluebottle/Physalia physalis), Bushrangers Bay, Australia ‘Despite their potentially dangerous sting, the bluebottle Cnidaria is an amazing creature. I wanted to demonstrate this with careful lighting and composition. The zooid colonies underneath them ignite with glorious translucent blue in the flash from my camera; I thought this would look magnificent in front of a glowing orange sky. After many early mornings, I eventually got my shot.’
displayImages.altText: Bluebottle Army - A Portuguese Man of War (AKA Bluebottle), Bushrangers Bay, NSW, Australia
displayImages.cleanCaption: Bluebottle Army: a Portuguese man o’ war (AKA bluebottle/Physalia physalis), Bushrangers Bay, Australia ‘Despite their potentially dangerous sting, the bluebottle Cnidaria is an amazing creature. I wanted to demonstrate this with careful lighting and composition. The zooid colonies underneath them ignite with glorious translucent blue in the flash from my camera; I thought this would look magnificent in front of a glowing orange sky. After many early mornings, I eventually got my shot.’

displayImages.caption: Silky Storm: silky sharks, Jardines de la Reina, Cuba ‘Shooting these sharks off the coast of Cuba was actually an incredibly difficult task. Not because they were hard to find – on the contrary, there were often too many, and they move very fast. So to single one out for an intimate portrait was quite frustrating. It required a high amount of concentration; luckily this one slowed down and peered into my lens just long enough for me to capture the shot.’
displayImages.altText: Silky Storm - Silky Sharks, Jardines de la Reina, Cuba
displayImages.cleanCaption: Silky Storm: silky sharks, Jardines de la Reina, Cuba ‘Shooting these sharks off the coast of Cuba was actually an incredibly difficult task. Not because they were hard to find – on the contrary, there were often too many, and they move very fast. So to single one out for an intimate portrait was quite frustrating. It required a high amount of concentration; luckily this one slowed down and peered into my lens just long enough for me to capture the shot.’

displayImages.caption: Janthina Janthina: violet snails, bass Point, Australia ‘Whenever there are large numbers of bluebottles around, these predacious snails won’t be far behind. They use a raft of bubbles to float on the ocean surface in search of floating hydrozoans to feed on.’
displayImages.altText: Janthina Janthina - Violet Snails, Bass Point, NSW Australia
displayImages.cleanCaption: Janthina Janthina: violet snails, bass Point, Australia ‘Whenever there are large numbers of bluebottles around, these predacious snails won’t be far behind. They use a raft of bubbles to float on the ocean surface in search of floating hydrozoans to feed on.’

displayImages.caption: Midnight Nudi: Hypselodoris bennetti, Bushrangers Bay, Australia ‘Being an ocean photographer has led me into some curious habits. Wading around in low-tide rockpools in the middle of the night is one of them. However, the rewards can be endless – such as finding this Hypselodoris bennetti in inches of water.’
displayImages.altText: Midnight Nudi - Bushrangers Bay, NSW Australia
displayImages.cleanCaption: Midnight Nudi: Hypselodoris bennetti, Bushrangers Bay, Australia ‘Being an ocean photographer has led me into some curious habits. Wading around in low-tide rockpools in the middle of the night is one of them. However, the rewards can be endless – such as finding this Hypselodoris bennetti in inches of water.’

displayImages.caption: Legal Immigrant: a long-finned eel, Botanical Gardens, Sydney ‘Born just off the coast of New Caledonia, this eel would have made the 2,000km journey to the east coast of Australia and, one wet night, climbed out of Sydney Harbour and slithered across the grass and into this freshwater pond, where it will live for up to 30 years. Eventually, the urge to breed will take it back across the south Pacific Ocean.’
displayImages.altText: Legal Immigrant - A Long Finned Eel, Botanical Gardens, Sydney
displayImages.cleanCaption: Legal Immigrant: a long-finned eel, Botanical Gardens, Sydney ‘Born just off the coast of New Caledonia, this eel would have made the 2,000km journey to the east coast of Australia and, one wet night, climbed out of Sydney Harbour and slithered across the grass and into this freshwater pond, where it will live for up to 30 years. Eventually, the urge to breed will take it back across the south Pacific Ocean.’

displayImages.caption: A Splash of Yellow: sargassum seaweed, Bushrangers Bay, Australia ‘You’ll find this seaweed pretty much everywhere along the coastline here in southern New South Wales. I lit it with a nice bright underwater strobe on a dark and rainy morning to give it that special something.’
displayImages.altText: A Splash of Yellow - Sargassum Seaweed, Bushranger Bay, NSW Australia
displayImages.cleanCaption: A Splash of Yellow: sargassum seaweed, Bushrangers Bay, Australia ‘You’ll find this seaweed pretty much everywhere along the coastline here in southern New South Wales. I lit it with a nice bright underwater strobe on a dark and rainy morning to give it that special something.’

displayImages.caption: New Pennies: silver bream, Bushrangers Bay, Australia ‘I’ve learned from diving in Bushrangers Bay that large schools of bream circulate early in the morning, especially during hot weather. I tried several ways of shooting them over the course of a few weeks, but decided this was my favourite way to portray them.’
displayImages.altText: New Pennies - Silver Bream, Bushrangers Bay, NSW Australia
displayImages.cleanCaption: New Pennies: silver bream, Bushrangers Bay, Australia ‘I’ve learned from diving in Bushrangers Bay that large schools of bream circulate early in the morning, especially during hot weather. I tried several ways of shooting them over the course of a few weeks, but decided this was my favourite way to portray them.’

displayImages.caption: Ocean Rose: waratah anemone, Bass Point, Australia ‘A beautiful crimson waratah anemone, the rose of the seabed, in a rockpool at Bass Point, New South Wales. These are native to Australia and New Zealand and named after the red waratah flower.’
displayImages.altText: Ocean Rose: Waratah Anemone, Bass Point, NSW Australia
displayImages.cleanCaption: Ocean Rose: waratah anemone, Bass Point, Australia ‘A beautiful crimson waratah anemone, the rose of the seabed, in a rockpool at Bass Point, New South Wales. These are native to Australia and New Zealand and named after the red waratah flower.’

cards.title: Bill Owens’ best photograph / A 1970s Tupperware party on thick shagpile
cards.rawTitle: A 1970s Tupperware party on thick shagpile

item.title: Bill Owens’ best photograph: a 1970s Tupperware party on thick shagpile
item.trailText: ‘Look at that shagpile! The woman hosting this Tupperware party bought a rake to make it stand up three inches’
item.standFirst: ‘Look at that carpet! The woman hosting this Tupperware party bought a rake to make it stand up three inches’
item.body:
When I left the Peace Corps, in the 1970s, I got a job as the staff photographer at a newspaper in Livermore, a small suburban city in California. It didn’t seem particularly well-to-do, but as soon as my wife and I got there we were in shock: everyone our age already had two cars, all the mod cons, everything. Because we’d lived abroad, we had nothing.

I decided to photograph the most normal things, the stuff people never think to show. I made a list of 200 classic suburban moments: people having barbecues, riding their bikes, doing the dishes, laying turf, playing Ping-Pong – and throwing Tupperware parties. I decided I wouldn’t set anything up or fake things. So when I got an invite to this party, I went along.

Tupperware is a classic, as American as apple pie. It’s tied up with the dream of plenty, but it’s also about being thrifty, so you can preserve both your food and your way of life. The woman hosting this party is standing beside me. She’s not in the shot. And look at her shag carpet! She’d recently bought a rake to make it stand up two or three inches. You could walk across it and see your footprints.

The lady standing up wasn’t friends with the others, though. She was a professional salesperson who went from town to town within a 30-mile radius, working on commission. Here she’s selling a standard eight-quart bowl and spinner. On the side of her coat you can see all the awards she’s won for outstanding sales. This woman devotes her life to selling Tupperware and she’s dressed up nice. I love her white boots. You wouldn’t know it from their deadpan faces, but I can assure you that this was a lively party. The ladies were all having fun. There’s a glass of wine in front of each of them, and that’s a sure sign of a good time.

Because I worked for the local newspaper, everyone knew who I was, which was important for my project. It’s not like being a photographer with National Geographic, where you work on one project for two months, then leave. I had to be there all year, invisible, to capture glimpses of real life, to show who we were as a nation. I wasn’t critiquing these people, though. I was fascinated by them. And it didn’t take my wife and me long to catch up with the suburban lifestyle. That American dream – two cars and a fridge full of food – is a way of life emulated by people all over the world.

Eventually, I had enough images to do my book, Suburbia. I kept a box of outtakes, the bad photographs, for 40 years. One day, I told my son I wanted to burn them, like Edward Weston did. But then I was contacted by a woman who told me she represented a collector who wanted outtakes. I said: “What? He wants all my prints that have been in a box?” Two months later, she told me she had sold 1,000 of them for $200 each and sent me a cheque for $200,000. I couldn’t keep that money, so I gave it to my son.

I’ve taken photographs that have been viewed by millions of people. It was me who photographed the Hells Angels beating people up at that Rolling Stones concert in Altamont in 1969. But I’m not proud of that image. I’m proud of the Tupperware. Who wants to photograph violence?

CV

Born: San Jose, California, 1938.

Studied: Self-taught.

Influences: Henri Cartier-Bresson, Robert Frank, Bruce Davidson.

High point: “Getting a Guggenheim fellowship.”

Low point: “When your wife leaves you because you don’t make any money.”

Interview by Kate Abbott

displayImages.altText: Tupperware by Bill Owens

headerImage.caption: ‘You could see your footprints’ … Tupperware, 1970s, by Bill Owens
headerImage.cleanCaption: ‘You could see your footprints’ … Tupperware, 1970s, by Bill Owens

cards.title: Documenting people / Mary Ellen Mark's legendary photographs

item.title: Mary Ellen Mark's legendary photographs
item.trailText: The award-winning photographer, who has died aged 75, was famed for her documentary work and intimate portraits, always regarding herself as a street photographer. Here are some of her most famous images

cards.title: Anti-austerity protest / Thousands march after Queen's speech

item.title: Thousands march against austerity cuts after Queen's speech
item.trailText: Several thousand people march on Westminster in protest against austerity cuts that will come into force under the newly elected Conservative government
item.standFirst: Several thousand people march on Westminster in protest against austerity cuts that will come into force under the newly elected Conservative government. Demonstrators took to the streets following the Queen's speech on Wednesday, which included further cuts public spending. At least three people were arrested when protesters broke through police lines and marched past Downing Street and the Houses of Parliament

cards.title: New York judge asked to rule on whether chimps are 'persons'
cards.rawTitle: New York judge asked to rule on whether chimps are 'persons'

item.title: New York judge asked to rule on whether chimps are 'persons'
item.trailText: Animal rights activists are attempting to assert the 'personhood' of two chimps who are being using as research subjects at a state university in New York
item.standFirst: Animal rights activists are arguing that a chimp can be a 'person'. The two chimps in question are being used as research subjects at a state university in New York. The activists hope a judge will rule the chimps be freed, allowing them to be taken to an animal sanctuary in Florida. An attorney for the state argues that the chimps, named Leo and Hercules, are not human

cards.title: At full time / Readers' photos of their football clubs
cards.rawTitle: Readers' photos of their football clubs

item.title: At full time: readers' photos of their football clubs
item.trailText: Another eventful football season has come to an end, and since August we’ve asked you for your photos and stories of your football club. Whether relegation is slowly sinking in, euphoric promotion parties are well under way or the summer will be spent analysing mid-table obscurity, here are some of your best efforts this season
item.standFirst: Another eventful British football season has come to an end, and since August we’ve asked you for your photos and stories of your football club. Whether relegation is slowly sinking in, euphoric promotion parties are well under way or the summer will be spent analysing mid-table obscurity, here are some of your best efforts this season

displayImages.caption:
Roma, Stadio Olympico, Rome
Now in my 30’s, I’ve watched Roma since I was a kid and Italian Football was on terrestrial TV. Many of my trips to Rome failed to coincide with a game, until December 14 when they finally matched, and I made it to my first live game. It included a relieving 93rd minute equaliser for the GialloRossi
Photograph: Brian Crawford/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Roma, Stadio Olympico, Rome Now in my 30's, I've watched Roma since I was a kid and Italian Football was on terresatrial TV. Many of my trips to Rome failed to coincide with a game, until December 14 when they finally matched, and I made it to my first live game. It included a relieving 93rd minute equaliser for the GialloRossi!
